title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Corinthians chapter 13 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Corinthians Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:1, how many times is the author coming to the Corinthians?
questions.correctAnswer: Third time
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:1 states, 'This is the third time I am coming to you.'

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 13:1 say establishes every word?
options: In the mouth of two or three witnesses
questions.correctAnswer: In the mouth of two or three witnesses
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established.'

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:2, what will the author do if he comes again?
questions.correctAnswer: He will not spare
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'if I come again, I will not spare.'

questions.question: Who is said to be mighty in you, according to 2 Corinthians 13:3?
questions.correctAnswer: Christ
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Since ye seek a proof of Christ speaking in me, which to you-ward is not weak, but is mighty in you.'

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:4, how does Christ live?
questions.correctAnswer: By the power of God
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'yet he liveth by the power of God.'

questions.question: What are believers instructed to examine according to 2 Corinthians 13:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Themselves
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Examine yourselves, whether ye be in the faith; prove your own selves.'

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 13:6 says the author trusts that the Corinthians are reprobates.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:6 states, 'But I trust that ye shall know that we are not reprobates.'

questions.question: What does the author pray the Corinthians will do according to 2 Corinthians 13:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Do no evil
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Now I pray to God that ye do no evil.'

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:8, what can the author do for the truth?
options: Nothing against the truth, but for the truth
questions.correctAnswer: Nothing against the truth, but for the truth
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'For we can do nothing against the truth, but for the truth.'

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 13:9 expresses gladness when the author is strong and the Corinthians are weak.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'we are glad, when we are weak, and ye are strong,' which is the opposite of the statement.

questions.question: Why does the author write these things being absent according to 2 Corinthians 13:10?
options: Lest being present he should use sharpness
questions.correctAnswer: Lest being present he should use sharpness
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'Therefore I write these things being absent, lest being present I should use sharpness.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from 2 Corinthians 13:11: 'Finally, brethren, farewell. Be perfect, be of good ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: comfort
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace.'

questions.question: What greeting does 2 Corinthians 13:12 instruct the believers to use with one another?
questions.correctAnswer: An holy kiss
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Greet one another with an holy kiss.'

questions.question: Who sends salutations to the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 13:13?
questions.correctAnswer: All the saints
questions.explanation: The verse states, 'All the saints salute you.'

questions.question: True or False: 2 Corinthians 13:14 mentions the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'The grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost, be with you all.'

medium.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is doubting their faith and asks how they can examine themselves to be sure they are truly in Christ. Based on 2 Corinthians 13, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Examine yourselves to see if you are in the faith and know that Christ is in you
Trust only in your feelings to confirm your faith
Rely on others to tell you if you are a true believer
Ignore doubts and continue without reflection
questions.correctAnswer: Examine yourselves to see if you are in the faith and know that Christ is in you
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:5 instructs believers to examine themselves and prove their faith, emphasizing personal spiritual self-assessment. Verses 5 and 6 encourage self-knowledge about Christ's presence within.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 13 teach us about dealing with sin in the church community?
options: If sin persists, the apostle will not spare discipline upon return
Ignore repeated sin to maintain peace
Allow sin to continue without correction
Publicly shame sinners without hope of restoration
questions.correctAnswer: If sin persists, the apostle will not spare discipline upon return
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:2 indicates Paul’s warning that if he returns and finds sin unrepented, he will not spare those who have sinned, highlighting the seriousness of church discipline for restoration.

questions.question: A believer feels weak and discouraged in their spiritual walk. According to 2 Corinthians 13, what encouragement can you give them?
options: God's power is made perfect in weakness, and we can live by His power
Weakness means God has abandoned you
You must be strong on your own without God's help
questions.correctAnswer: God's power is made perfect in weakness, and we can live by His power
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:4 and 9 show that Christ was crucified in weakness but lives by God's power, and believers, though weak, can live by that power. Verse 9 expresses gladness in weakness while others are strong.

questions.question: What does 2 Corinthians 13 teach about the attitude believers should have when facing correction or discipline?
options: Correction is for edification, not destruction, and should be used carefully
Discipline should be harsh and destroy those who sin
Use correction to assert personal power
questions.correctAnswer: Correction is for edification, not destruction, and should be used carefully
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:10 emphasizes that correction is given by the power of the Lord for building up (edification), not for tearing down (destruction), reflecting a loving and constructive approach.

questions.question: How does this passage instruct believers to live together in the church community?
options: Be of one mind, live in peace, and comfort one another
Compete to be the most popular member
Ignore others’ needs and focus only on yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Be of one mind, live in peace, and comfort one another
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:11 calls believers to unity, peace, and mutual comfort, showing the importance of harmony and encouragement within the church family.

questions.question: What spiritual blessing does Paul pronounce upon the believers at the end of 2 Corinthians 13?
options: The grace of Jesus, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit
Freedom from all trials and hardships
questions.correctAnswer: The grace of Jesus, the love of God, and the fellowship of the Holy Spirit
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:14 pronounces a Trinitarian blessing highlighting grace, love, and spiritual fellowship as foundational blessings for believers.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with honesty in their work. According to 2 Corinthians 13, what principle should guide their behavior?
options: Do what is honest regardless of appearances
Act dishonestly if it benefits you
Only be honest when others are watching
questions.correctAnswer: Do what is honest regardless of appearances
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:7 encourages doing what is honest even if others consider them reprobates, highlighting integrity over outward approval.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Corinthians 13, Paul seeks to do anything against the truth to defend himself.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:8 states that Paul can do nothing against the truth but only for the truth, showing his commitment to honesty and integrity.

questions.question: How does this passage teach us about the importance of fellowship among believers?
options: Believers should greet one another with a holy kiss as a sign of love and unity
Keep to yourself and avoid social interaction
Fellowship is unnecessary for spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Believers should greet one another with a holy kiss as a sign of love and unity
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:12 instructs believers to greet one another with a holy kiss, symbolizing affectionate fellowship and unity in the church.

questions.question: Based on 2 Corinthians 13, what should be the believer's attitude toward weakness and strength within the body of Christ?
options: Be glad when weak and others are strong, and wish for their perfection
Avoid admitting weakness to appear perfect
Ignore others’ strengths and focus only on yourself
questions.correctAnswer: Be glad when weak and others are strong, and wish for their perfection
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:9 expresses gladness in weakness when others are strong and a desire for their perfection, showing humility and prayerful support.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to despair because of past sin. What hope does 2 Corinthians 13 offer regarding restoration?
options: Christ is alive by God's power, and believers will live with Him by that power
Sin is unforgivable and leads to rejection
No hope exists after repeated failure
Only external actions matter, not inner change
questions.correctAnswer: Christ is alive by God's power, and believers will live with Him by that power
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:4 assures that though Christ was crucified through weakness, He lives by God's power, and believers share in that life and power toward restoration.

questions.question: True or False: Paul writes this letter to avoid using sharpness and destruction when he visits the Corinthians in person.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:10 explains Paul’s purpose in writing while absent to avoid using sharpness and destruction when present, seeking edification instead.

questions.question: How does 2 Corinthians 13 instruct us to handle disagreements within the church?
options: Be of one mind and live in peace to promote unity
Fuel arguments to prove your point
questions.correctAnswer: Be of one mind and live in peace to promote unity
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:11 urges believers to be of one mind and live in peace, fostering harmony and unity in the church.

questions.question: Which of the following best summarizes Paul's confidence regarding his ministry among the Corinthians?
options: He trusts that he and the Corinthians are not disqualified (reprobates)
He doubts his effectiveness and expects failure
He seeks to appear approved by people rather than God
He plans to abandon the ministry if challenged
questions.correctAnswer: He trusts that he and the Corinthians are not disqualified (reprobates)
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:6 shows Paul’s confidence that both he and the Corinthians are not reprobates, affirming their genuine faith and ministry.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 2 Corinthians 13:1 says, 'In the mouth of two or three ______ shall every word be established.'
questions.correctAnswer: witnesses
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:1 states that the testimony of two or three witnesses is required to establish every word, emphasizing the principle of confirmation.

hard.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Corinthians Chapter 13.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:1, what principle is established concerning the confirmation of every word?
options: In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established
By the testimony of a single prophet
questions.correctAnswer: In the mouth of two or three witnesses shall every word be established
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:1 quotes the principle that every word must be confirmed by two or three witnesses, reflecting Deuteronomy 19:15 and Jewish legal tradition.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:3, Paul refers to a proof of Christ speaking in him. What does he claim about this proof?
options: It is mighty in you, not weak
It is a mystery not understood
It is only for the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: It is mighty in you, not weak
questions.explanation: Paul asserts in 2 Corinthians 13:3 that Christ’s speaking through him is powerful and effective among the Corinthians, emphasizing divine strength rather than human weakness.

questions.question: What theological contrast does Paul draw in 2 Corinthians 13:4 regarding Christ's crucifixion and resurrection?
options: Christ was crucified through weakness but lives by the power of God
Christ was mighty in crucifixion but weak in resurrection
Christ's death was a myth, but his resurrection is real
Christ never truly died but appeared to be crucified
questions.correctAnswer: Christ was crucified through weakness but lives by the power of God
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:4 contrasts Christ’s apparent weakness in crucifixion with the divine power manifested in His resurrection, illustrating a typology of weakness and strength.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:5, Paul urges the Corinthians to examine themselves. What is the purpose of this self-examination?
options: To prove whether they are in the faith
To assess their wealth and status
questions.correctAnswer: To prove whether they are in the faith
questions.explanation: Paul commands self-examination in 2 Corinthians 13:5 to determine genuine faith and the indwelling presence of Christ, highlighting personal spiritual accountability.

questions.question: What does Paul express confidence in regarding himself and his companions in 2 Corinthians 13:6?
options: That they are the only righteous
That they are apostles of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: That they are not reprobates
questions.explanation: In 2 Corinthians 13:6, Paul expresses trust that they are not rejected or disqualified, affirming their genuine apostolic authority and integrity.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:7, what does Paul pray for the Corinthians?
questions.correctAnswer: That they do no evil
questions.explanation: Paul’s prayer in 2 Corinthians 13:7 focuses on moral integrity and honesty among the believers, prioritizing righteousness over outward approval.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:8, Paul states they can do nothing against what, but only for what?
options: Against the truth, but for the truth
Against the law, but for freedom
Against the Gentiles, but for the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: Against the truth, but for the truth
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes in 2 Corinthians 13:8 his commitment to truth, showing that his actions and words serve to uphold divine truth, not contradict it.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:9, Paul expresses gladness when they are weak and the Corinthians are strong. What does this reflect in terms of Pauline theology?
options: The paradox of strength through weakness
questions.correctAnswer: The paradox of strength through weakness
questions.explanation: This verse reflects the Pauline theme of paradox where human weakness allows God's strength to be more clearly demonstrated, a concept also seen in 2 Corinthians 12:9.

questions.question: Why does Paul write these things being absent, according to 2 Corinthians 13:10?
options: So that he would not use sharpness when present
Because he is afraid to visit
questions.correctAnswer: So that he would not use sharpness when present
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 2 Corinthians 13:10 that his intent is to edify, not destroy; by writing now, he can warn without immediate confrontation.

questions.question: What final exhortations does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 13:11?
options: Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace
questions.correctAnswer: Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace
questions.explanation: Paul’s closing exhortations in 2 Corinthians 13:11 emphasize unity, peace, and spiritual maturity among the believers.

questions.question: What cultural greeting does Paul instruct the Corinthians to use in 2 Corinthians 13:12?
options: Greet one another with a holy kiss
questions.correctAnswer: Greet one another with a holy kiss
questions.explanation: The 'holy kiss' mentioned in 2 Corinthians 13:12 is a culturally significant greeting in early Christian communities symbolizing fellowship and unity.

questions.question: Who sends greetings to the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 13:13?
questions.correctAnswer: All the saints
questions.explanation: Paul notes in 2 Corinthians 13:13 that the entire community of believers, referred to as 'all the saints,' send their salutations, showing communal solidarity.

questions.question: 2 Corinthians 13:14 contains a Trinitarian benediction. Which three divine persons are mentioned?
options: The Lord Jesus Christ, God, and the Holy Ghost
The Father, the Son, and the Angel of the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord Jesus Christ, God, and the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: This verse presents a clear Trinitarian formula invoking Jesus Christ, God the Father, and the Holy Spirit, highlighting early Christian doctrine.

questions.question: True or False: In 2 Corinthians 13:2, Paul threatens that if he comes again, he will not spare those who have sinned.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Paul clearly states in 2 Corinthians 13:2 that upon his next visit, he will not spare those who have sinned, emphasizing accountability.

questions.question: Which Old Testament principle is directly alluded to in 2 Corinthians 13:1 regarding witnesses?
options: Deuteronomy 19:15 about the testimony of two or three witnesses
questions.correctAnswer: Deuteronomy 19:15 about the testimony of two or three witnesses
questions.explanation: Paul's reference to two or three witnesses in 2 Corinthians 13:1 echoes Deuteronomy 19:15, establishing a legal standard for confirmation of truth.

theological.title: 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Corinthians Chapter 13 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:1, how is every word established?
options: In the mouth of two or three witnesses
By the testimony of a single prophet
questions.correctAnswer: In the mouth of two or three witnesses
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:1 states that every word shall be established in the mouth of two or three witnesses, reflecting the biblical principle also found in Deuteronomy 19:15 and Matthew 18:16 that multiple witnesses confirm truth.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:3, Paul says a proof of Christ speaking in him is not weak but what?
questions.correctAnswer: Mighty in you
questions.explanation: Paul emphasizes in 2 Corinthians 13:3 that the proof of Christ speaking in him is 'mighty in you,' showing the power of Christ working in believers, consistent with John 14:12 and Philippians 4:13.

questions.question: What does Paul say about Jesus Christ in 2 Corinthians 13:4?
options: He was crucified through weakness but lives by the power of God
He was never crucified but only appeared so
He lives only in the hearts of believers
He is absent until the end of days
questions.correctAnswer: He was crucified through weakness but lives by the power of God
questions.explanation: 2 Corinthians 13:4 confirms the paradox of Christ's crucifixion showing weakness but His resurrection demonstrating divine power, aligning with Philippians 2:8-9 and Romans 1:4.

questions.question: What does Paul instruct believers to do in 2 Corinthians 13:5?
options: Examine yourselves whether you are in the faith
questions.correctAnswer: Examine yourselves whether you are in the faith
questions.explanation: Paul calls for self-examination in 2 Corinthians 13:5 to verify true faith, consistent with passages like Lamentations 3:40 and 1 John 4:1-3 emphasizing testing one's spiritual condition.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:7, why does Paul pray that believers do no evil?
options: Not for Paul's approval but that they do what is honest
So Paul will be recognized as right
questions.correctAnswer: Not for Paul's approval but that they do what is honest
questions.explanation: Paul's prayer in 2 Corinthians 13:7 highlights the desire for believers to do what is honest and right regardless of human approval, echoing Proverbs 21:3 and Romans 12:17-21.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:8, Paul says they can do nothing but what?
questions.correctAnswer: For the truth
questions.explanation: Paul declares in 2 Corinthians 13:8 that they can only act for the truth, emphasizing integrity and faithfulness, consistent with John 18:37 and Psalm 15:2.

questions.question: What does Paul express gladness over in 2 Corinthians 13:9?
options: When they are weak and the believers are strong
When he is wealthy and others are poor
questions.correctAnswer: When they are weak and the believers are strong
questions.explanation: Paul states in 2 Corinthians 13:9 that his joy is when he is weak and the believers are strong, illustrating the paradox of Christian ministry as in 2 Corinthians 12:9 and Philippians 3:10.

questions.question: Why does Paul write these things being absent, according to 2 Corinthians 13:10?
options: Lest being present he should use sharpness according to the Lord’s power for edification
To show his authority over them
questions.correctAnswer: Lest being present he should use sharpness according to the Lord’s power for edification
questions.explanation: Paul writes with the aim of building up rather than tearing down, as stated in 2 Corinthians 13:10, aligning with Ephesians 4:12 and Hebrews 12:11 about correction for growth.

questions.question: What final exhortations does Paul give in 2 Corinthians 13:11?
options: Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace
questions.correctAnswer: Be perfect, be of good comfort, be of one mind, live in peace
questions.explanation: Paul’s final charge in 2 Corinthians 13:11 calls for spiritual maturity and unity, reflecting themes found in Romans 12:2, Philippians 2:2, and Colossians 3:15.

questions.question: How are believers instructed to greet one another in 2 Corinthians 13:12?
options: With a bow from a distance
questions.correctAnswer: With a holy kiss
questions.explanation: The holy kiss as a greeting, mentioned in 2 Corinthians 13:12, symbolizes Christian love and fellowship, also found in Romans 16:16 and 1 Thessalonians 5:26.

questions.question: According to 2 Corinthians 13:14, which three divine persons are mentioned in the benediction?
options: The Lord Jesus Christ, God, and the Holy Ghost
God the Father, angels, and saints
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord Jesus Christ, God, and the Holy Ghost
questions.explanation: The benediction in 2 Corinthians 13:14 explicitly mentions the three persons of the Trinity, emphasizing grace, love, and communion, consistent with Matthew 28:19 and Jude 1:20-21.

questions.question: In 2 Corinthians 13:2, what warning does Paul give if he comes again?
options: He will not spare those who have sinned
questions.correctAnswer: He will not spare those who have sinned
questions.explanation: Paul warns in 2 Corinthians 13:2 that upon his next visit he will not be lenient toward sin, demonstrating the seriousness of holiness, in line with Hebrews 12:6 and Revelation 3:19.

questions.question: What does Paul say about himself and his co-workers in 2 Corinthians 13:6?
options: They are perfect and without sin
They are judges over the church
They are strangers to the faith
questions.correctAnswer: They are not reprobates
questions.explanation: Paul expresses confidence in 2 Corinthians 13:6 that he and his companions are not rejected or disqualified, emphasizing their apostolic legitimacy, similar to 1 Timothy 1:12 and 2 Timothy 2:15.

questions.question: How does Paul describe weakness and life in 2 Corinthians 13:4?
options: We are weak in Christ but shall live by God's power
We are strong and never weak
Weakness is sin and leads to death
Life is independent of God’s power
questions.correctAnswer: We are weak in Christ but shall live by God's power
questions.explanation: Paul explains in 2 Corinthians 13:4 that though Christians may be weak, they live through the power of God, echoing 2 Corinthians 12:9 and John 15:5.

questions.question: What does Paul desire for the Corinthians in 2 Corinthians 13:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Their perfection
questions.explanation: Paul's wish for their 'perfection' in 2 Corinthians 13:9 aligns with the biblical call to maturity found in Ephesians 4:13 and Hebrews 6:1.
